newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan approves record low China investments.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan approves record low China investments.

text.p: Taiwan said on Saturday it approved the lowest number of investment projects ever in China for a single month in September, indicating local companies were heeding government advice to slow their mainland businesses.
The economics ministry said in a statement it approved 16 indirect Taiwanese investment projects in China worth US$46.4 million in September, down from 31 worth $122 million in August.
The government, fearing that the island's economy would become overdependent on China's market, has been urging businesses to cool their pace of investment in the mainland.
"The (record low number of cases) shows the government's current investment policy towards the mainland has received the cooperation of our enterprises," the ministry said in the statement.
From January to September, the ministry said it approved investment of $956 million in 285 projects to China, down 90 cases but up $127.53 million from the same period in 1995.
"This shows that our investments to China are becoming larger-scale projects," the ministry said.
Taiwan has banned direct investments to China since the two separated after a civil war in 1949. All projects must be routed through a third territory, mostly Hong Kong.
The ministry added it approved $345.7 million foreign investments in Taiwan in September, up $145.97 million from August.
It attributed the rise to foreign firms applying to set up ventures in Taiwan's newly-opened mobile phone industry -- including a $123.6 million project by U.S.-based SBC Communications Inc.
The government part-liberalised the telecommunications industry in January, opening up some areas for private and foreign investments.
The ministry approved $156.26 million in 32 cases of Taiwan's overseas investments in countries other than China, down nine cases but up $46.835 million in value from August.
